1.text: The safe wouldn't open even with a hit... so I hit it harder. The lid flew off, and the contents... well, let's just say the noble will need another safe. I apologized, but I think he was more upset that I saw what was inside.

2.text: The noble seemed desperate, but there was nothing magical or complicated about the safe — just a worn lock system. I just listened for the right click and... done. He turned pale when I opened it. 'Strictly personal,' he said. I just smiled and left without looking inside.

3.text: The safe spoke to me... or maybe it was the sound of the gears. Either way, I used holy water, touched the lock, and it opened. I think the secret was engraved in the owner's mind, but it might also have been a miracle. The voices told me not to look inside, and I obeyed.

4.text: The lock was mechanical, not magical, so I tried to solve it logically: I calculated the possible angles, forced the pins with precise electrical discharge... and the safe opened! The smell of burnt metal was just a technical bonus. The contents... irrelevant. Efficiency is what matters.

1_2.text: There was no need to break the safe, Lyra. It only needed a delicate touch and attention to the sound of the gears.
But you took so long looking at it... I thought it was a trap.
It was just a safe, not an enemy. And the noble was quite satisfied — until he realized I saw what was inside.
Oh... sorry. I didn't look. Almost.

1_3.text: The safe whispered to me, Lyra. It wanted to be opened gently.
I tried to be gentle... but it broke first.
The voices said your strength is a prayer without words. I think the safe understood that too.
So... it's okay?

1_4.text: The safe's structure was solid, but with enough energy, I could open it without destroying anything.
I just hit it until it opened.
...Functional, but inefficient. But I admit it was fast.
Thanks... I guess.

2_3.text: I just needed to hear the right click, and the safe opened.
The voices said you have the ears of true angels of precision.
Angels or training. Either way, I didn't look at what was inside.
The voices approved.

2_4.text: The lock was simple. It just took attention and lightness.
I would have used low-voltage electricity to map the pins. But your approach was... clean.
Clean and without risk of explosion, which is already an improvement.
Agreed. Statistically, you are correct.

3_4.text: The safe had voices trapped in it, Leo. They whispered numbers.
Or they were just vibrating metal pins. Predictable frequencies.
Or divine revelations.
Perhaps both.

1_2_3.text: Lyra wanted to solve it by force, but this time it was better to listen to the sound of the lock.
I... was just testing if it was resistant.
The voices said that metal yields to patience, not to a blow.
Then the safe opened. And the noble... pretended nothing happened.

1_2_4.text: Lyra, you almost split the safe in half!
But you opened it first... just a little slower.
Electrical efficiency would have been superior, but Elara's method was more... human.
Thanks... I guess.

1_3_4.text: Lyra broke the seal with pure faith. I heard the voices celebrating.
It wasn't voices. It was the sound of metal yielding under absurd force.
Sorry... I just wanted to help.
And you helped. Miraculously.

2_3_4.text: It was just a matter of listening for the right click. No magic or brute force.
The voices said you have blessed hands.
Or excellent motor coordination. Both true.
Thanks, I guess.

1_2_3_4.text: While you were discussing methods, I just listened to the sound of the lock... and opened it.
I was going to hit it, but you were faster.
The voices said: 'The truth opens doors'.
And safes, apparently. Statistically, she's right.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I will train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable movement and lost my position. It's a mistake in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three straight days, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I tried to help the druid, but every time I saw a trap, I... ended up crushing everything around it. The woods got a bit... flattened. But I didn't see any animals caught after that, so I guess it was a success?

2.text: The woods were full of hidden traps — hooks, wires, iron teeth. I had to move slowly, listen to the wind, feel the ground. I disarmed each one without breaking anything. The druid cried with relief. I just asked him to make sure no one hunted there again.

3.text: The traps were cruel. The metal seemed to laugh... but the voices guided me. They said: 'Touch carefully.' I made the holy sign and the springs opened, one by one. The druid thanked me. The voices fell silent — which is always a good sign.

4.text: The traps had simple pressure triggers. I could have solved everything with precise electrical discharges, but there was a risk of fire. I calculated the tension points and deactivated them mechanically. Pure efficiency, no collateral damage. The druid praised the scientific method.

1_2.text: Each trap was made to wound without killing. I had to be careful with the weight of my steps.
I tried not to step, but... well, the ground gave way anyway.
You literally tore half the trap out with your hands.
But it worked, right?

1_3.text: Lyra, the woods were crying. The voices asked for silence and lightness.
I tried to be light, but... I think I broke three branches.
The voices said your strength is innocent, like a startled deer. I think they forgave you.
Oh... that's good.

1_4.text: Most of the traps were rusty. I could have disarmed them all with electrical precision.
I just broke the chains. It was faster.
Fast, yes. And noisy. But I admit... functional.
Thanks!

2_3.text: Each trap seemed made by someone merciless. I used calm and controlled breathing.
The voices said you weave peace with your hands. The woods thanked you.
I don't know about the woods, but the druid seemed happy.
The voices laughed. That's good.

2_4.text: The mechanisms were simple, but dangerous. You just had to touch the right spot.
Impressive. I would have used an electrical scan, but your technique was... impeccable.
No need for sparks. Just precision.
Pure dexterity. Almost scientific.

3_4.text: The voices said the traps have a soul. Hurting the forest hurts the world.
Or perhaps just rudimentary pressure sensors.
Sensors... or hearts of iron. It all depends on who is listening.
I agree... in a way.

1_2_3.text: Lyra, try not to step there—
Too late!
The sound echoed, but the voices said: 'Nothing was hurt.' I think it worked.
In the end, yes. And the woods survived, thanks to luck... and a little care.

1_2_4.text: Each trap had a different trick. It was quite a challenge.
Your coordination is statistically notable. No explosions, no fire.
But a branch flew off. Does that count?
It counts... if no one was hurt.

1_3_4.text: The forest whispered requests for mercy.
Or it was the wind, reverberating through the leaves.
I just heard a snap... and broke the trap.
The important thing is that the animals are free. Whether by faith, calculation, or strength.

2_3_4.text: I used caution to disarm the traps without damaging the ground.
The voices approved. They said the touch of truth is lighter than the wind.
And mathematically efficient. No miscalculation detected.
Thanks, I guess.

1_2_3_4.text: Everyone helped as they could. Lyra pushed branches away, Kael prayed, Leo analyzed the mechanism.
And you disarmed it before I broke it, right?
The voices said this was a beautiful dance.
Dance... statistically synchronized. And effective.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I will train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable movement and lost my position. It's a mistake in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three straight days, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I tried to... talk to them. But when they started shouting, I ended up holding both chiefs and... well, they stopped fighting. I guess it was effective. I apologized afterward, of course. They were breathless for a while, but they came to an understanding.

2.text: They were ready for war, so I just told them the truth — that both tribes were being manipulated by the messenger to give up supplies for free. They were confused, then outraged... but at the messenger, not at each other. Mission accomplished, I think.

3.text: The voices were restless... they said blood called for blood. But I asked for silence and heard something else: an ancient echo of fear. I made the tribes pray together. For a few moments, I felt the world breathe. The war... dissolved.

4.text: I tried to logically explain that the loss of supplies could have been caused by night predators or counting error. I made calculations. I showed probabilities. No one understood. So I made a small demonstration with lightning — they understood that quickly.

1_2.text: Lyra thought they'd solve it with conversation, but when they started pushing each other...
I just held the two of them, gently. I mean... I tried to be gentle.
They stopped instantly. I don't think they'll ever argue again.
It was accidental. But... it worked.

1_3.text: The weight of anger was dense there. I heard ancient prayers calling for blood.
Then I... took the chiefs and sat them on the ground. I told them to listen to Kael.
And they listened. Her strength imposed silence, and faith did the rest.
I never thought that... intimidating could help people pray together.

1_4.text: I tried to mediate the conversation logically, but no one listened to me.
They were shouting too much. So... I enforced silence.
Yes. Literally. She held the two leaders until they heard my explanation.
It worked, didn't it?

2_3.text: Kael started talking about voices and faith, and I just... kept watching.
The voices guided the right words. They needed to hear repentance.
I confirmed everything he said, word for word. The truth calmed both tribes.
And faith closed the wound.

2_4.text: Leonardo started with numbers, I with sincerity. Then they got even more confused.
The confusion was necessary to reorganize the collective reasoning.
Or maybe they just got tired of arguing.
Satisfactory result, either way.

3_4.text: Leonardo calculated causes, I prayed for calm. The voices said: 'one needs the other'.
The data indicated external manipulation. The probabilities matched what he... heard.
It was beautiful. Science and faith, side by side.
It was... coherent. In a strange way.

1_2_3.text: The tribes were on the verge of killing each other. I felt the fear pulse.
Then I... made them sit down. Nobody fights sitting down.
And I just told them the truth: that the messenger was using them.
And peace came. Strength, truth, and faith. An unlikely balance.

1_2_4.text: The dispute was illogical. So I presented facts.
They ignored them until Lyra lifted one of the chiefs into the air.
I just wanted him to listen to me...
And he listened. Miraculously.

1_3_4.text: The voices asked for silence. Lyra understood even before I spoke.
They were fighting... so I stopped the fight. Physically.
And while she held them both, Kael started a sermon. I just translated it into logic.
And for a moment, the world believed.

2_3_4.text: The situation was tense, but Kael and Leo understood each other in a... unique way.
He did calculations, I did prayers. The sum was peace.
Probability of success increased by 87% when Elara told the naked truth.
See? Truth always helps.

1_2_3_4.text: There was fear, anger, and despair. But also hope.
I identified logical flaws in the accusations. Elara confirmed with sincerity.
And Lyra... well, she ensured no one lifted a weapon.
They just wanted to be heard... I think we achieved that together.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I will train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable movement and lost my position. It's a mistake in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three straight days, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: The cult seemed... calm. Everyone smiled too much. I tried to watch quietly, but one of them looked at me strangely. They asked if I felt the 'inner light.' I just said I felt like leaving. When they tried to stop me, I... pushed. Too hard. The altar broke, and their smile vanished.

2.text: They talked about purity and peace, but the way they looked at the newcomers was... strange. I watched and realized the leaders had the same memorized phrases. I asked if they could repeat them without the chant — they froze. Then I understood: it wasn't faith, it was command. I said it out loud and the spell broke.

3.text: Their silence was rehearsed. The voices whispered to me that the song didn't go up, it went down. I heard a sound of iron in the middle of the prayer and felt the lie vibrate. When the leader raised the chalice, I knocked it over and he screamed — as if the false god had died inside him. The voices... were quiet after that.

4.text: The cult seemed harmless at first glance. There were rhythmic patterns in the chants, all too synchronized. I took measurements and noticed subtle variations in hypnotic frequency. I concluded it was emotional manipulation. I interrupted the chant with an electric snap. Everyone regained consciousness in seconds.

1_2.text: The cult was... strange. Everyone smiled the same way.
They seemed too happy. When one of them tried to touch me, I pushed. The wall fell down.
And the spell too. I think your sincerity was... physical.
I don't know how to lie or hide strength.

1_3.text: The voices whispered: 'it's not light, it's hunger'.
I didn't understand, but I saw the leader sweating. Kael told me to step away.
The spell broke when I smashed the chalice. The false god died without a sound.
It was... scary. But beautiful too, somehow.

1_4.text: The chants formed a sequence of collective hypnosis.
They looked at me and asked me to smile. I tried... I couldn't.
Your emotional resistance broke the pattern. After that, I just needed to interrupt with electricity.
I still don't like places that sing too much.

2_3.text: The voices warned me. The chants were empty — soulless repetition.
I noticed too. The priest's answers were all memorized.
I broke the rhythm with an ancient prayer. The illusion tore.
No one was hurt. They just... woke up. They seemed relieved.

2_4.text: The vocal repetition pattern created emotional dependency.
And the followers didn't even know they were trapped in it.
We corrected the sound, the cycle broke. End of manipulation.
Sometimes, just stopping the repetition is enough.

3_4.text: The voices spoke of a lie disguised as prayer.
The sound pattern confirmed it. There was a pulse of coercion in the air.
When I asked for silence, the spell broke. Faith became faith again.
It was... scientifically beautiful, I admit.

1_2_3.text: The faces were too serene. The voices shouted: 'lie'.
I tested the leader with simple questions. He froze, as if someone had erased his mind.
I just broke the altar. Just in case.
And true faith breathed again.

1_2_4.text: The chants formed a structure of collective control.
And every sentence was a lie. I heard it. I could feel it.
When the leader raised the chalice, I... broke it.
It was effective. The system collapsed immediately.

1_3_4.text: The voices cried. They said the cult wasn't praying — it was draining.
Kael told me to hold the chalice. It was shaking, but I managed.
His prayer nullified the temple's energy. The magical structure collapsed.
And the false god fell silent.

2_3_4.text: The priest spoke for another. The voices asked to reveal the disguise.
The numbers showed illusory coherence. Mental manipulation proven.
I told everyone what we saw. The truth cut the spell.
The lie cannot stand the light.

1_2_3_4.text: The cult pretended purity. The voices shouted: 'it's empty'.
Artificial magical energy detected. The pattern was inverted.
The leader was lying the whole time. I just pointed it out.
And I... just prevented him from escaping. The chalice fell. It was all over.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I will train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable movement and lost my position. It's a mistake in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three straight days, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: The stone was... enormous. I kept staring and trying to think of something else, because there were too many people waiting and that makes me a little nervous. So I just put my hands on it and pushed. I heard it crackle, then slide. When I realized it, the passage was open. And everyone was staring at me... again.

2.text: The stone was too big for me to move. So I tried to analyze the terrain. I saw a looser part underneath. I used an improvised lever and moved it bit by bit. It took a while, but it worked. I didn't steal anything, I didn't break anything — I just used the truth of physics, I guess.

3.text: The stone was too quiet. The voices said it wanted to fall to the correct side, but it was stuck in fear. I touched it and said a short prayer. The wind changed and the rock gave way, as if sighing. It wasn't force. It was... conversation. Sometimes it works.

4.text: The stone had a greater weight than I could move, so I analyzed the point of least resistance. I applied controlled electric discharges for superficial fragmentation. Small fissures formed, and I was able to dismantle the block into smaller pieces. Rational, efficient and... slightly fun.

1_2.text: The stone was gigantic, but Lyra just stood there, looking at it in her way.
I... pushed. I thought it would just scratch it, but it slid right out.
I was preparing levers and calculations, but... well, force works.
Sorry if I scared you when the stone started moving fast.

1_3.text: The stone whispered fear. I heard it. It didn't want to stay there.
I just put my hand on it and pushed. I didn't hear anything, just the sound of the stone.
It responded to your strength. Strength is also a prayer, sometimes.
I never thought of that, but... thank you.

1_4.text: I was assessing the possibility of fragmenting the block with moderate lightning.
I thought it was simpler to just push.
Indeed. The direct method was statistically efficient this time.
I was just afraid of hitting you when it rolled down the hill.

2_3.text: I tried to find the loose point of the rock, but it really wouldn't move.
It was stuck in its own emotional weight. The voices told me.
I don't know about stone emotions, but your prayer made it give way.
It wanted to go. It just needed someone listening.

2_4.text: I tried to move the stone with a lever, but it didn't move much.
I applied electric discharges to open strategic fissures.
After that, I managed to displace the pieces calmly. Without breaking anything but the stone.
A good joint effort of precision and... physical sincerity.

3_4.text: The stone was divided between staying and going. The voices were arguing with it.
There was enough structural tension for fragmentation. I used electricity for that.
The voices gave thanks. Even cracked, the stone found peace.
Peace is an interesting concept for geology.

1_2_3.text: The stone silently screamed for change.
I tried to help with a lever, but I couldn't compete with Lyra.
I just pushed. I didn't want to get in anyone's way.
You didn't get in the way. You liberated it.

1_2_4.text: I was already calculating the necessary discharges.
I was looking for weak spots.
I just... pushed.
And eliminated the need for any other method.

1_3_4.text: The stone was crying. Or it seemed like it. The voices were agitated.
I thought about breaking it into smaller pieces.
I pushed before you finished deciding.
And the weight disappeared — in every sense.

2_3_4.text: The stone was arguing with the wind. I tried to calm it down.
I tried to loosen its base with a lever.
I applied precise electricity and the structure yielded.
Putting it all together, it finally moved.

1_2_3_4.text: The stone was stuck, but not by earth — by hesitation.
I was analyzing possible break points.
I was about to try displacing it from the base.
I pushed. Then everything was resolved.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's an error in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: The failure was inevitable. The voices screamed 'Wrong Way' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: The bell was bigger than I imagined. The bishop kept staring as if he was sure I could do it... and that made me even more nervous. I took a deep breath, hugged the base of the bell, and lifted slowly. My arms trembled, but it went up. When I fit it on the top, the bishop started crying. He thanked me in front of everyone. I wanted to disappear.

2.text: I couldn't lift the bell by force, so I decided to set up an improvised pulley system. It took me a while to tie everything securely. I said exactly what I was doing, so no one would think it was a trick. When I pulled, the bell rose slowly, groaning, but it went up. The bishop said it looked like a miracle. I explained it was just physics.

3.text: The bell... it was afraid of heights. The voices said so. I stood there, talking quietly with it, explaining that ringing higher would be good for everyone. Then I said a long prayer, one I didn't remember learning. When I finished, the bell became light. Not actually light — but light enough for me to guide it to the top. I think it accepted its destiny.

4.text: I analyzed the weight and realized that moving it directly would be unfeasible. I then calculated a support structure with planned electric discharges to contract and expand dry ropes, creating momentary traction. It wasn't meant to be elegant, but it worked. The bell rose in precise impulses and was fixed on top. The bishop thought it was divine intervention. I... let him think that.

1_2.text: When I saw the size of the bell, I started preparing ropes. Then I looked at Lyra and realized I might be overthinking it.
I just... grabbed the bell and lifted. I didn't want to mess up your plan.
You didn't mess up. You solved it. And I saved ropes.
Sorry for lifting it so fast. I heard you say 'careful', but it was already in the air.

1_3.text: The bell was trembling. The voices said it didn't want to go up.
I didn't hear any of that... I just felt it was very heavy.
But you convinced it using muscles. That's also persuasion.
I... I don't know how to persuade anyone. I just lifted.

1_4.text: I was calculating a method to create electric traction on the ropes.
I thought it was faster to just lift it with my arms.
Indeed. Your variables are... surprisingly efficient.
I was just afraid of dropping the bell when you said 'careful' really loudly.

2_3.text: I tried to set up pulleys, but the bell barely moved.
It resisted. Said it wasn't ready to ring out to the sky.
Your prayers changed something. After that, it went up with less effort.
I just explained it would have company up there.

2_4.text: I tied the ropes, but even pulling hard, it wouldn't go up high enough.
Then I applied discharges to adjust the traction. Just enough not to burn anything.
After that, it went up as if it were light. It's not a trick, I swear.
Not a trick. Just... electrical engineering.

3_4.text: The bell whispered doubts. I tried to calm it down.
I calculated electric impulses to generate small, successive elevations.
It agreed to go up after that. Said it trusted us.
Attributing trust to a bell is... conceptually curious, but it functioned.

1_2_3.text: The bell needed courage, said the voice from the top.
I was going to use pulleys, but Lyra was already holding the bell.
I... just lifted. I didn't want to take too long.
The bell was thankful. I was too.

1_2_4.text: I calculated a way to electrically propel the bell.
I held the ropes to stabilize it.
I had already lifted it when you finished talking.
Yes. Your method was... immediate.

1_3_4.text: The bell hesitated. The voices were agitated.
I was already preparing controlled discharges.
I lifted it before you started.
The voices said that was kind.

2_3_4.text: The bell didn't want to go. That was clear.
I tied ropes and tried to pull, but it didn't go up enough.
I used electricity to create vertical impulses. Summing everything up, it worked.
In the end, it seemed like we had rehearsed this before.

1_2_3_4.text: The bell talked a lot. A lot.
I calculated three possible elevation methods.
And I was adjusting ropes for safety.
But I had already lifted the bell while you were talking.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's an error in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: The failure was inevitable. The voices screamed 'Wrong Way' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error was not tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I… tried to understand those erased runes, but… nobody explained that a portal could screech like a pot about to explode. I got nervous and… hit the stone until it stopped shaking. I don't know if that was right, but the glow stabilized. Yeah… it worked, I guess.

2.text: I don't understand anything about portals, but I tried to be careful. The runes were faint, so I touched each one until I figured out which ones reacted. I didn't cheat, nor did I try to activate it dangerously. I just followed what they ‘wanted’ to show. In the end, the portal lit up as if it were relieved.

3.text: The voices said the portal was sleeping, waiting for a touch that wasn't of fear. I ran my fingers over the runes and they lit up, one by one, as if answering. I don't know if it was faith, madness, or chance… but it opened its eyes of light without devouring anyone.

4.text: The runes were fried. Literally almost out of charge. I compared the patterns with arcana discharge cycles and… well, I had to reorganize everything. The portal stabilized again when I aligned the current with a minimal lightning strike. Almost perfect. Almost. It vibrates a bit, but it won't explode the valley. I think.

1_2.text: I thought we were just going to observe, but the portal was about to open by itself. I touched the fainter runes so as not to cause an accident.
It started shaking hard… I got scared. So… I pushed the frame. Hard. Very hard.
The truth is it worked. After she pushed, the runes aligned as if they were startled and obeyed.
I… didn't want to scare anyone. Just… stop the noise. At least the portal opened correctly in the end.

1_3.text: The voices told me the portal was crying inside. I touched the runes to calm it down.
When it started vibrating too much, I thought it was going to fall on us… so I held the base with everything I had.
It was funny… the runes only lit up after she held the portal as if hugging an insecure giant.
I didn't hug it! I mean… I just prevented it from falling. But… if it helped, that's good.

1_4.text: The portal's discharge was misaligned. I had to calculate the flow while it was destabilizing. It was beautiful… and dangerous.
He asked me to hold the portal arch steady. I was afraid of breaking it, but… I held it very slowly.
Slowly my foot. She stabilized the portal as if she were holding a bull with one hand. It was perfect for the calculation.
I just… didn't want to let go and let everything fall. But I'm happy I helped.

2_3.text: The runes seemed insecure, as if they only needed a little nudge to wake up.
I whispered to the portal and it answered. The voices said it remembered me.
I don't know if that's true, but… when he spoke to Kael, some runes did glow.
And when you touched the shy ones, they lit up for good. It was beautiful.

2_4.text: The pattern was broken. It needed energy reordering. It wasn't difficult, it just… required electric focus.
I felt which runes were the most fragile and only touched the ones that wouldn't freak out with a shock.
That helped a lot. You prevented me from overloading the matrix. The runes became… aligned.
I'm happy it worked. I don't like risking exploding anyone, even by accident.

3_4.text: The voices showed me the path of the runes, but they were silent. Something was stopping them from shining.
They weren't silent, just discharged. I used a minimal lightning flow to reignite the pattern.
The portal opened like a giant eye… and winked at me. I think.
It just realigned the arcane iris. But… if it comforts you to think that, that's fine.

1_2_3.text: I tried to sense which runes still had some energy so as not to cause an accident.
I heard the portal crying. The runes wanted company.
When it started shaking, I… held the portal before it fell.
As soon as she held it, everything calmed down. I was able to talk to it.

1_2_4.text: The pattern was absurd, as if someone had placed the runes upside down.
I went touching them one by one to find the stable ones.
And… I held the portal when it threatened to twist.
You were perfect. That way I was able to discharge and recharge the circuit without frying the mountain.

1_3_4.text: The voices told me the portal was afraid.
It doesn't feel fear. It was just uncalibrated.
I just held the frame when it started screeching… again.
And that saved everything. I managed to apply the discharge without knocking anyone over.

2_3_4.text: The portal needed a three-point alignment. It was… fascinating.
I touched the runes that seemed most stable so as not to interfere.
And I spoke to it. It listened. The runes smiled.
They didn't smile. They just lit up. But the timing was perfect.

1_2_3_4.text: It was a beautiful chaos. I could almost feel the teleport trying to recompose itself.
The runes were disturbed, so I only touched the safe ones.
I heard the portal's call. It wanted to awaken.
When everything started shaking, I held the entire structure. I thought it would break… but it didn't.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's an error in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices screamed 'Wrong Path' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I reached the crystal in the east wing and it was shaking… so I just shoved it hard into the socket. It worked. I think.

2.text: When I saw the sparks, I realized it was just a crooked arcana wire. I adjusted it and said — just for the record — that I wasn't illegally tampering with anything.

3.text: I touched the crystal and heard a plea for help. I prayed, or something close to it, and the energy calmed down. Me too.

4.text: The crystal had an unbalanced charge. I touched it with a light lightning bolt to align it. It looked good afterward.

1_2.text: Lyra held the crystal as if it were a falling jar. I just watched, making sure nothing was illegal.
I… just didn't want it to fall.
After you firmed it up, it was possible to align the wire without risk.
That's good… I was afraid of squeezing too hard.

1_3.text: Lyra, the crystal was screaming. Didn't you hear? It was screaming inside.
I just saw it wobbling… so I stopped the wobble.
Your way is silent, but efficient. The voices stopped afterward.
I… I'm happy it worked out.

1_4.text: I was going to equalize the charge, but you shoved the crystal first. It didn't explode, so… good job.
Sorry… it seemed urgent.
It helped. With it steady, I managed to adjust it perfectly.
Oh… then that's good.

2_3.text: Kael, you were talking to the crystal as if it were answering. I decided not to interfere.
It did answer, yes. In a sad way. Did you feel the sadness?
I only felt static… but it really was the crooked wire.
Your crooked wire made silence. Silence is good.

2_4.text: Leo said he was going to give a 'light touch.' I didn't think he meant literally.
Light for me is minimum charge equalization. Literally, yes.
Well… it worked. I just aligned the support afterward.
It was well tidied up in the end.

3_4.text: The sparks looked like impatient fingers. Did you see that, Leo?
To me it was just off-axis charge… but I understand the metaphor.
Metaphor or not, you calmed the fingers.
The equalization did resolve it well.

1_2_3.text: The crystal was sparking too much. I said I wasn't illegally tampering, but I needed to adjust the wire.
It was suffering. I felt it. It was asking for help.
I just held it firmly so it wouldn't fall.
And that made everything easier to fix.

1_2_4.text: When we arrived, the crystal looked like it was giving up on life. Lyra grabbed it right away.
I… saw it was falling.
With it steady, I was able to equalize the charge perfectly.
And I aligned the base and that was it. Quick trio.

1_3_4.text: The crystal was sobbing energy. It was sad.
To me it was just bad charge, but… okay, it did sound like a sob.
I just fitted it back in…
And the sobbing stopped. It became calm again.

2_3_4.text: I started by saying I wasn't doing anything illegal. Just for the record.
The crystal doesn't care about laws. It just wanted to stop hurting.
It wanted stable charge, that's what.
Well… we fixed everything together. It worked.

1_2_3_4.text: The crystal almost fell apart when we arrived. I immediately warned it wasn't my fault.
I held it… maybe too hard.
That helped a lot. We were able to balance the energy without risk.
And in the end, the voices stopped. Everything became light again.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's an error in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices screamed 'Wrong Path' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I went down the well and the slime came straight towards me… I gave it a strong blow right in the middle. It splattered, but stopped moving. I climbed out quickly because the smell was awful.

2.text: When I saw the slime down there, I said out loud that I wouldn't take anything from it, just for the record. I landed my blows perfectly, it lost its shape and dissolved.

3.text: The slime looked like a sick sigh from the bottom of the well. I touched my symbol and the light spread… it melted as if it were too tired to continue.

4.text: I went down, saw the slime accumulating, and only thought about the texture. I threw a lightning bolt straight into its core. It evaporated so fast it made a funny sound. The water cleaned up instantly.

1_2.text: The slime tried to jump at me, but I dodged and said I wasn't touching it by my choice. Lyra solved it with force.
I just… hit it with everything I had.
It worked well. It splattered, but stopped immediately.
I was happy when it stopped moving.

1_3.text: That slime was whispering… or maybe it was just the well. But it seemed restless before you hit it.
I hit fast. I wanted to finish quickly.
Your blow made it dissolve. Then I just needed to illuminate the rest.
Thank you… for helping with the light.

1_4.text: When you hit it, the slime trembled all over. I could see the exposed core, which made my lightning strike easier afterward.
I just aimed where it seemed softest…
It was good. With it stopped, I could finish it off perfectly.
I'm glad it worked out.

2_3.text: The slime almost slipped on me, but I dodged and made it clear I didn't want anything from it. Kael finished the rest with… light? Or something like that.
The light came easily. It was weak, I could feel it.
It only dissolved after your magic.
And the water became calmer too.

2_4.text: I hit the slime the right way and it loosened its shape. Then Leo just… did his thing.
The unstable form helped me. I just finished it off with a shock right in the center.
It was fast. I didn't even have time to try anything else.
Slimes react well to electricity. I found it amusing.

3_4.text: The slime seemed to be asking for silence, but at the same time it made strange noises.
To me it was just gelatinous vibration. Nothing mystical.
I used my light to weaken it. It almost melted on its own.
Then I just finished off the rest. It made a satisfying crackle.

1_2_3.text: When we went down, the slime came up as if I were stealing from it, but I immediately said I didn't want anything from it.
It was confused, I could feel it.
I attacked to get it away from us.
With it disorganized, my light finished the job.

1_2_4.text: Lyra went straight to the attack and the slime lost its shape immediately.
I just wanted to stop it from coming up.
When you hit it, I saw the core exposed. Then it was just a matter of aiming the lightning.
And it disappeared quickly. I didn't even smell it afterward.

1_3_4.text: The slime seemed restless… as if it were afraid of us.
I… attacked anyway. It charged first.
Your blow made room for me to hit the core with lightning.
And the light I gave afterward cleaned the rest of the water.

2_3_4.text: The slime tried to stick to my leg. I dodged and made it clear I wanted no contact.
It seemed desperate… but it dissolved when I touched it with the light.
And then I finished it off with lightning when it was too soft to react.
The water cleaned up almost instantly.

1_2_3_4.text: The slime almost slipped on me, but I dodged in time.
I attacked it to keep it away from you.
The blow made room to hit the core without risk.
And in the end, my light cleaned up what was left.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's an error in planning and execution, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices screamed 'Wrong Path' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model had only a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I... I went back there. The well still smelled a little weird, but... I went down fast. When I saw that pile of slime moving, I just... hit it. Hit it hard. They stuck to the floor and tried to jump at me, but I got a bit... nervous, so I ended up crushing everything before thinking too much. I felt embarrassed afterwards because... I made too much noise. But it worked, I guess.

2.text: I returned to the well thinking this time would be simpler, but the little slimes were multiplying. I tried to tell myself not to jump right in, but... well, I jumped right in. I used the bucket as a distraction and hit the little creatures with precise movements. It wasn't elegant, but it was honest: I just wanted to stop them from getting out of there. In the end, they stopped moving. I also stopped for a bit to breathe.

3.text: I went down to the well and the small forms trembled as if whispering something only I could hear. Maybe it was just the water... or maybe not. I touched the symbol on my chest and asked for clarity. The light answered, and the slimes... withered, as if they had given up. The voices said this wasn't the end, but they say so many things. The important thing is: it's quiet down there, for now.

4.text: I went down to analyze, but when I saw the little slimes... I kind of had an immediate idea. They reacted to small electrical charges, so I... tested intensities. I only wanted to find the dissipation threshold, but I ended up... hitting them with a continuous blast. They vaporized. I mentally noted everything. It was... good. Very good.

1_2.text: Lyra went down first and I almost slipped trying to keep up, but the little slimes were everywhere. I told her we could solve it without breaking anything, but...
S-sorry... I just saw them coming and my body was faster than my head. I hit before I thought.
Yeah, I saw. And I admit that... it worked. I just kept dodging what flew around while hitting the smaller ones.
Thanks for not complaining... I promise to try to be gentler. Someday.

1_3.text: The small creatures pulsed like hearts outside the body. Lyra seemed restless, but I thought the light could calm them.
They weren't stopping... I was afraid they would jump on you. So... I sped up a bit.
The light didn't mind your force. In fact, it told me it was in a hurry. Maybe it was just my head.
If... if it said so, then it's right. I'm glad you're okay.

1_4.text: Lyra went down so fast she almost made me lose count of the discharges I wanted to test.
S-sorry... they were moving too much and I got nervous.
It's fine. While you were crushing the big ones, I managed to focus a beam on the small ones. It was efficient. Even a little beautiful.
Beautiful? Oh... thank you. I, huh... don't know how to react to that.

2_3.text: The creatures were whispering in a strange way. I told Elara that, but she said it was just the sound of the water.
It's just that I didn't hear anything but... slime smacking. I just tried to hit the biggest ones before they stuck to you.
You were precise. The light thought so too. I think it did. It changes its mind.
Look, whether it was light or echo, it worked. And no one got stuck, so... victory.

2_4.text: I wanted to at least measure one of the slimes before you started hitting them, but I understand it was urgent.
Sorry, Leo... I saw them trying to climb your foot, so I just... reacted.
I noticed. But while you took care of the bigger ones, I managed to discharge a controlled pulse. It cleanly evaporated the smaller ones.
It was much cleaner than my boots. But thanks. Saved the moment.

3_4.text: The small masses trembled at a rhythm that seemed... almost regular. I asked Leo if he saw it too.
I didn't see a rhythm, but I saw excessive moisture reacting to electricity. So I just... activated an arc.
And they withered. The light said it was a clean end. Maybe it was just your magic.
Perhaps. But it worked. And it was... satisfying.

1_2_3.text: There was a lot of slime... I almost tripped when I went down, sorry.
Relax, Lyra. I was dodging and hitting the smaller ones while you were crushing the big ones.
And the light helped extinguish the rest. It said you were... aligned. I don't know exactly what that means.
If... if it helped, then good. I get less nervous when you two are around.

1_2_4.text: They jumped a lot... I felt like I needed to act fast.
And you did. I just tried not to get hit by the pieces while finishing off the small ones.
I took advantage of the chaos and fired a continuous electric arc. It dissolved the rest cleanly.
I... I hope I didn't mess up your calculations, Leo.

1_3_4.text: I was afraid the slimes would stick to you, so I started too quickly.
Haste is sometimes a divine answer. Or an illusion. Today I thought it was useful.
While you were crushing the bigger ones, I managed to align a perfect beam. It evaporated the small ones.
Thank you... I feel calmer with you two nearby.

2_3_4.text: The scene was pretty ugly down there... I tried to dodge and hit without making noise.
Noise or not, they trembled as if they responded to our arrival.
I solved that with an electric pulse. Simple. Efficient.
Yeah... clean, at least. Better than being all sticky.

1_2_3_4.text: I... I didn't know where to start. There was a lot of slime.
We improvised. You crushed, I finished off what escaped.
And the light closed the gaps. At least for now.
Meanwhile, I applied precise discharges to eliminate the smaller ones. It was organized. My way.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's a planning and execution error, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model only had a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I... ended up crushing everything too quickly. I felt a bit awkward when the farmer thanked me exaggeratedly, but... it was good to help.

2.text: The slimes were numerous but slow. I cleared them one by one and warned the farmers not to step on the remains. Honest work.

3.text: The creatures crackled when I touched them with the sacred symbol. They seemed confused. I did what I could to dissipate each one of them.

4.text: They moved slowly... sometimes even fascinatingly. I shot small, controlled lightning bolts. The field was cleaned quickly.

1_2.text: I was about to slice a slime and Lyra had already crushed three. It even threw me off my rhythm.
S-sorry... I just... thought it best not to let them get close to you.
It's fine, it was efficient. I just had to chase the leftovers myself.
At least the farmer was happy. I... was too.

1_3.text: Lyra hit so hard that some slimes almost evaporated. The voices laughed about it.
I-I didn't want to make a mess... but they were coming fast.
Mess purifies sometimes. Today it worked.
If you say so... I feel better.

1_4.text: Lyra crushed while I calculated angles. It was... strangely efficient.
I just wanted to help you not get too dirty...
Uh... thank you. The lightning bolts did spread less goo, yes.
That's good. I'm happy.

2_3.text: We slowly cleared the field. I was slicing and Kael... making strange noises.
The voices wanted to see how they exploded. I kept it minimal, I swear.
Well... the important thing is that it worked.
Yes. The field is peaceful for now.

2_4.text: Leo aimed, calculated... and I just finished off the ones that escaped.
You move too fast. I had to adjust everything about three times.
Sorry. But I think it was well done.
It was. Precisely well done.

3_4.text: I tried to dissipate them peacefully, but Leo shot light over me.
It wasn't over. It was a calculated angle. Precision matters.
The voices found it amusing. I just followed the rhythm.
It worked. Field clear.

1_2_3.text: Lyra took care of the biggest ones, I sliced the medium ones, and Kael... did what Kael does.
S-sorry if I overdid it... I didn't want to scare anyone.
Scaring purifies. Sometimes. The voices approved.
Well... in the end it worked. Field clear.

1_2_4.text: We almost became a production line. Lyra, me, Leo. Repetitive... but good.
The patterns became clear quickly. And efficient.
I just tried to keep up with you two...
And you kept up very well. It was great.

1_3_4.text: Lyra crushed, Leo thundered, I murmured. A strange harmony.
The distribution was good. Each one solved a part.
I'm glad it helped...
It helped, yes. The voices fell silent in the end.

2_3_4.text: It was fast. I sliced, Kael murmured, and Leo calculated trajectories.
I adjusted three times, but in the end it worked.
The voices found it organized.
Yes... organized we certainly were.

1_2_3_4.text: With four people this almost became a task force.
I needed to recalibrate several times. But it was worth it.
I tried not to get in the way...
You helped, Lyra. Everyone helped. The field is peaceful.

1.text: I tried... but there were more slimes than I imagined. I couldn't protect the field properly.

2.text: I was as fast as I could, but there were too many of them. I feel like I failed the farmers.

3.text: The voices warned me... I should have listened better. I couldn't contain them all.

4.text: My magic failed in sequence. I didn't calculate correctly. I could have avoided this.

1_2.text: I couldn't keep up with the quantity. It was frustrating.
I-I couldn't hold them all either... sorry.
It's not your fault. We just couldn't handle it.
We should have been able to...

1_3.text: They were too many... and the voices became restless.
I did what I could... but it wasn't enough.
Neither did I. The voices lamented for us.
I'm sorry for the field...

1_4.text: I missed several calculations. They escaped...
Sorry... I failed too.
Lacked synchronization. In both of us.
I hope it can be fixed later.

2_3.text: I ran, I sliced... but they surrounded us too quickly.
The voices screamed. I lost focus.
It's not your fault. It was too big.
Even so... we failed.

2_4.text: I tried to clear the front, but they came from the sides.
I didn't see the approach. My mistake.
It was both our mistake. The field suffered.
We can do better next time.

3_4.text: I tried to stay calm... but the creatures didn't stop.
My calculations failed. I couldn't keep up with your pace.
Even I couldn't keep up.
We failed. That's all.

1_2_3.text: Even together, we couldn't handle it.
I tried to protect you all... I tried.
The voices cried for the field.
We are sorry. All of us.

1_2_4.text: They surrounded us in waves... we couldn't predict it.
I should have seen the pattern. I failed.
Sorry... I failed too.
It's not your fault, Lyra. We just... failed.

1_3_4.text: The voices screamed that more would come. They did.
I couldn't deal with so many at once.
I tried... but I couldn't keep the pace.
There are three of us... and still it wasn't enough.

2_3_4.text: I sliced and sliced... but the number didn't decrease.
The voices became desperate.
I lost the pattern completely.
It was too much for the three of us.

1_2_3_4.text: Even with four... it didn't work.
The voices said it was a bad omen.
I failed the calculations. Again.
I... I'm sorry for all of us.

1.text: I... I tried to get close to the puddle. It vibrates. It seems like it wants to lift. I hit it a bit, but slowly. I didn't want it to... fully wake up.

2.text: I got close to the puddle. It ripples as if it has breath. I'm not lying. I touched it with the dagger hilt and it reacted as if it had a will of its own.

3.text: It was calling for something. Not for me this time, but for air. For form. I felt it in my chest. I gave the blessing and the light entered it. It went out.

4.text: Its surface had enough tension to react to any magic. That's perfect for a discharge. I released a small bolt... and it completely fell apart.

1_2.text: Lyra, I touched it very lightly and it trembled as if it was about to lift. That's not normal.
I... I thought it was going to jump on us. That's why I hit it a bit. Not hard. Just to make it stop.
It didn't stop much though. It just spread out more. I didn't like it.
If it grows bigger, I'll have to hit it for real. Then... sorry if it splashes on you.

1_3.text: Lyra, it wanted to rise. I felt it. As if it had a heart waiting for the moment.
I was afraid it would breathe. I heard... like a gasp.
I gave light. A lot. It dissolved, as if it had given up on existing.
Thank you... I didn't want to see what it was going to turn into next.

1_4.text: Lyra, its texture was accumulating energy. Almost asking for a stimulus.
It seemed... restless. I don't like it when things get restless.
I discharged a bolt. Small. Just to see the reaction. It completely fell apart.
That was fast. I thought I would have to hit it. Glad I didn't have to.

2_3.text: It tried to stick to my dagger hilt again. But this time... it seemed stronger.
That's because it was growing inside. I felt it. As if it was ready to be born.
Don't say 'be born', Kael. That makes everything worse.
The light entered it... and it gave up. It spread out, quiet.

2_4.text: Leo, promise me you won't stick your hand in there.
I only wanted to measure the temperature. It was too hot in the center.
Hot is not normal. Nothing hot is good in slimes.
The bolt dismantled everything. Not even a pattern left to analyze afterwards.

3_4.text: Leo, it was calling. Not you. Something that was inside.
I only saw a lot of trapped energy. Enough energy to turn into something else.
I gave light. You gave a bolt. It didn't stand a chance.
Yes. Clean end. No reaction afterwards.

1_2_3.text: It was trying to lift its own body. I felt it on my skin.
I'm not doubting it. It pulled the dagger as if it had a will of its own.
It was... bigger than before. Much bigger.
The light fixed it. It went out. It didn't resist.

1_2_4.text: Its center had too much accumulated energy. It was dangerous.
It vibrated when I got close. I didn't like that one bit.
I was going to hit it... but you acted fast.
The bolt dismantled everything. Better this way.

1_3_4.text: It had structure. Real structure, trying to form something.
Something that wanted to get out. I felt it calling for it.
I got... scared. Of the size.
Light and bolt together were enough. No form was left.

2_3_4.text: Okay, it was much bigger. And stickier. And weirder.
It wanted to stand up. I heard it. Loudly.
That explained the accumulated energy. It was a lot, indeed.
It ended when we made it light up inside. It disappeared slowly.

1_2_3_4.text: Its energy was at the limit. It was dangerous to let it grow.
It asked for form. It asked for release.
I just wanted it to stop trying to pull my things.
Good thing you two... made it disappear. I didn't want to fight what was going to come out of there.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's a planning and execution error, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model only had a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I... I dealt with the goblins. It... was fast. They attacked first, I just... shoved one of them and it flew too far away. I didn't mean to scare anyone, but before I knew it, it was over. The village is safe... I think.

2.text: I found the goblins near a clearing. They gave us some trouble, but nothing unexpected. The strange thing is that I tracked extra footprints besides the ones we faced. I didn't lie to myself: they were goblin prints, but... more than the number we saw. I just couldn't figure out where they went.

3.text: The goblins... they were restless. I heard murmurs, but not from them. Something nearby was whispering words that didn't match the wind. I fought anyway. The voices didn't interfere much this time. I think the goblins were running from something, not going to attack. It's just... a feeling.

4.text: The goblins reacted predictably. They always react that way when someone conjures an electrical discharge in their direction. I did the calculations: low physical resistance + high environmental conductivity = quick victory. Just a curious detail: I counted more footprints than goblins in the combat. I couldn't follow all of them, because... well... I had lightning to focus on.

1_2.text: Lyra dealt with the goblins in a very direct way. I tracked where they were and noticed more footprints than the number we encountered. I didn't hide that — it seemed wrong to ignore. But when we got there, Lyra just... charged. It worked, in a way.

Elara found everything. I just... did my part. She mentioned the extra footprints, but I couldn't see them properly. When the goblins rushed us, I got nervous and... shoved one of them too far. Sorry.
She apologizes, but she doesn't need to. She solved the hard part. I just followed the tracks — including the extra ones, which remain unexplained. I didn't want to pressure anyone with that.
I... I feel calmer when she talks like that. It's good to have someone who understands where to step before I ruin the ground with too much force.

1_3.text: The voices were agitated near the goblins. Nothing to stop me from acting. Lyra seemed uncomfortable, but firm. When the first goblin advanced, she knocked it down as if it were too light. The voices even silenced for a moment.

I just wanted to help... but Kael kept staring into nothing sometimes. I didn't know if I should ask. When the goblins came, I just... did what I needed to. They were so small... I was afraid of overdoing it.
She overdid it, yes, but in a useful way. The voices seemed satisfied. Or annoyed. Or... yeah, I don't know. But she kept us alive.
I... I'm glad it worked out. I hope I didn't make the voices angry.

1_4.text: Lyra always surprises me. I had a well-organized electrical plan, but before I could launch the second beam, she had already knocked down half the goblins with brute force. Impressive. It messes up my calculations a bit, but impressive.
Sorry, Leo... I... I thought you needed time. I just hit them a little too hard.

No need to apologize. Your strength is... efficient. I just wish I had measured the impact better. Oh, and I counted more footprints than defeated goblins. That stayed in my mind, but the fight took my focus away.
If you want to measure... I can hold a goblin next time. Carefully.

2_3.text: I tracked the goblins and found extra footprints. I didn't hide any of this from Kael, but he kept looking at the horizon and murmuring things. Even so, he fought well. The goblins didn't know where to run — and I also didn't understand where those footprints came from.

The footprints... yes. Some moved, others didn't. At least that's what the voices said. Maybe none of them were real. Elara always tells the truth, so I trusted her analysis. We attacked together and it worked.
I prefer it when he doesn't describe the footprints as 'perhaps non-existent', but it worked. And he didn't get lost in the voices this time.
Because you speak clearly. That helps to silence a lot in my head.

2_4.text: I tracked the goblin group and found footprints beyond theirs. I told Leo, of course. He kept staring at the ground as if he were solving an electrical enigma. When the goblins appeared, he already had magic gathered.

Yes, I tried to follow the extra prints, but the terrain had a different resistance than expected. That distracted me. When the goblins showed up, I preferred to focus on the lightning — much more predictable.
He really is calmer when everything involves calculations. In the end, the goblins fell fast. But the footprints still bother me.
They bother me too. But not as much as the unevenness of the soil in that area. That keeps me up at night.

3_4.text: The air was heavy. I heard voices commenting on footsteps that weren't ours. I asked Leo to confirm, but he was busy analyzing the soil... and preparing lightning. When the goblins advanced, the voices became agitated, but we managed to deal with it.

Yes, there were extra footsteps. Not as many as Kael described, I think. I only counted a few. But I was more interested in the air's humidity — perfect for electrical conduction. That helped a lot in the fight.
The voices disagree, but they disagree with everything. The important thing is that it worked.
Yes. It worked. I still want to measure the electric field of that area again.

1_2_3.text: I tried to follow Elara without making noise... but I think I failed. When the goblins appeared, I got nervous. I hit them too hard. Kael was murmuring strange things, but he seemed calm.
I told them about the extra footprints. I still think that's very strange. Lyra tried to be careful, but she is... too strong for that. It's okay, she solved the hard part.
The footprints... some were there, others maybe not. Lyra scared even the voices when she knocked down the first goblin. Elara was the only one who walked with clarity in all that confusion.
I'm glad that... that you didn't think I overdid it. I just wanted to help.

1_2_4.text: I saw Elara crouch down to look at the footprints. She mentioned more tracks than goblins. That made me nervous. When they appeared, I hit them too fast... I think I scared Leo a bit.
She hit hard, yes. But better hard than slow. I just followed the footprints — including the extra ones. And Leo stood still analyzing the air, I think.
The air had accumulated static. That was important. And yes, I saw extra footprints, but I couldn't follow them. Lyra ended the fight before I could test the discharge I wanted to use.
Sorry, Leo. Next time... I'll wait for your test.

1_3_4.text: I stayed close to the two of them, but Kael was saying things I didn't understand. Leo seemed distracted by sparks in the air. When the goblins arrived, I just... shoved one and ended up knocking down the others too.
The voices said they were afraid. Not of us — of something behind them. But when Lyra knocked them down, everything went silent. I like that silence.
I confirm that the chain reaction of Lyra's force was... impressive. I also noticed extra footsteps before the fight, but I didn't have time to analyze them.
If you want... I can try not to knock down so many at once next time.

2_3_4.text: I followed the goblin tracks. There were extra footprints, yes. I told the two of them. Kael started hearing things, Leo started analyzing the soil. I just kept walking.
The voices got confused with the noise of the footsteps. Not all the prints were true... I think. But when the goblins appeared, I managed to focus.
The terrain had strange density. That affected my electric discharge calculation. Even so, we defeated the goblins quickly.
Yes. But I keep thinking about those extra footprints. I don't like leaving things unexplained.

1_2_3_4.text: I tried to follow you slowly... but when the goblins came, I got in front without thinking. Sorry if I got in the way.
You didn't get in the way, Lyra. The extra footprints still bother me, but the fight was quick. You solved the hard part.
The voices got confused with so much information. But when Lyra attacked, they quieted down. That always helps me think.
I was going to test a new discharge, but Lyra finished everything beforehand. I still want to go back there to analyze the extra tracks.

1.text: I... I wasn't strong enough. My sword... didn't reach. I'm sorry for the guild. I'll train until I don't fail anymore.

2.text: I failed. I was caught in a predictable move and lost my position. It's a planning and execution error, and I must accept the consequences. The precision was insufficient.

3.text: Failure was inevitable. The voices shouted 'Wrong Way' for three days straight, but I insisted on ignoring them. The error wasn't tactical, it was one of discernment. We lost.

4.text: The data we had was incomplete or flawed. Our success model only had a 38.7% probability, but we acted anyway. The result is statistically expected. We need more analysis and less haste.

1.text: I followed the path in the most direct way possible. I'm not good with tracks, but I found drag marks in the dirt and kept following them. Before I knew it, I was standing in front of a huge cave, with a giant rock blocking everything. I returned to notify the guild.

2.text: I managed to separate the correct trails. The goblins tried to confuse us, but not enough. I followed the most recent route, and it led directly to a cave sealed by a huge rock. I wrote everything down before returning.

3.text: The voices told me to follow the turned-over earth... and for some reason, they were right. I walked through winding trails until they all converged on a cave capped by a colossal rock. It was as if... someone wanted to hide something inside. I preferred to turn back.

4.text: I analyzed patterns of footsteps, speed, and group dispersion. Even with so many crossing trails, there was coherence. They led to a cave with a huge rock blocking the entrance. The formation seemed intentional. I recorded it and returned.

1_2.text: I was guiding the way. The trails were numerous, but I managed to filter the false ones. Lyra just kept following me silently.
I... I just followed Elara. She seemed very sure of the path. I didn't get in the way, I think.
The deeper marks showed a larger group. That led us to the sealed cave.
The rock at the entrance was enormous. It couldn't be moved. So we returned with the report.

1_3.text: The voices indicated confusing directions... but they all led to the same spot.
I tried to look at footprints too, but there were too many. In the end, we followed what Kael was saying.
All the trails converged on a cave blocked by an immense rock.
That rock seemed impossible to move. We just noted it and went back.

1_4.text: I analyzed soil patterns. Even without a tracker, it was possible to identify the dominant direction.
I was, uhm... pushing bushes and testing paths. Maybe it helped a little.
The trails all ended in front of a cave with a giant rock at the entrance.
It was too big to move. So we returned to the guild with what we saw.

2_3.text: I handled the technical part of the tracking. There was too much trail, but I managed to find the main path.
The voices confirmed it... almost like an echo coming from the disturbed earth.
The path led us to the cave sealed by the immense rock.
The place seemed... stifled. As if it were guarding something. We decided not to interfere.

2_4.text: The goblins tried to cover the trails, but the trick didn't work on me.
I just followed and recorded patterns. Elara saw everything before me.
The most consistent route ended in a cave with a huge rock blocking the entrance.
I took quick measurements and we returned. Nothing would pass through that rock.

3_4.text: There were many trails... but the voices spoke of heavy footsteps and recently disturbed earth.
I identified displacement patterns. Many routes, but they all formed a funnel.
That funnel led to a cave completely blocked by a giant rock.
The formation seemed deliberate. We recorded it and returned.

1_2_3.text: I did the main tracking. The false trails were well made, but nothing impossible.
The voices confirmed the direction. That helped rule out some detours.
I mostly stayed in the rear... just trying not to get in anyone's way.
The real path led to the sealed cave. The enormous rock is still there.

1_2_4.text: I followed the correct trails while the two analyzed other possibilities.
Elara found the dominant route even before I finished my calculations.
I kept watching the flanks to ensure nothing approached.
Everything ended at the cave blocked by the huge rock. We returned with the report.

1_3_4.text: The voices spoke of irregular movements... all the trails seemed intended to deceive.
I tried to analyze patterns. Even confused, they all converged at the same point.
I was clearing the path so we could get through.
In the end, we reached the cave sealed by an enormous rock. We didn't touch it.

2_3_4.text: I identified which of the trails was the real one. There were many, but I managed to filter them.
The voices approved every step... which was strange, but useful.
I ran quick terrain analyses: everything led to the same point.
The blocked cave with the huge rock was at the end of the path.

1_2_3_4.text: I did the main tracking. With so many extra eyes, it was easier to cut useless paths.
I checked patterns. Elara had already found the way even before I finished.
The voices just repeated: 'all trails lead to the same hole'.
The cave with the giant rock... that's what we found. And we rushed back to tell.

1.text: I searched and ruined some trails with my footsteps, but in the end I didn't find the origin. I felt terrible.

2.text: There were so many confusing marks that I was mistaken twice; I lost time and came back empty-handed.

3.text: The voices became uncertain and sent me in circles. I didn't bring back anything useful.

4.text: My measurements were contradictory — I should have been more careful. I failed to locate the cave.

1_2.text: I tried to follow the footprints, but the marks were confusing.
I ended up making more noise and I think we lost the tracks.
I got two false negatives.
I came back upset.

1_3.text: The voices and I disagreed on the path.
I was embarrassed for having messed up how to press down a root.
We went in the wrong direction.
Nothing found.

1_4.text: My readings were not confirmed on the terrain.
I ended up knocking over a stump that erased marks.
We lost the trail and came back.
I'm sorry.

2_3.text: The trail I found was old; I lost the real lead.
The voices asked for calm, but there was nothing left to follow.
We misread the signs.
We came back empty-handed.

2_4.text: I found a route, but my points were incomplete.
The data didn't match; I preferred not to insist.
We were left without confirmation.
We returned without result.

3_4.text: The voices changed tone and confused us.
My measurements were nullified by light rain.
We found nothing but old footprints.
No progress.

1_2_3.text: I tried to map it, but the trail was lost.
I knocked down something that erased marks.
There were only echoes, no direction.
We came back frustrated.

1_2_4.text: The reading failed where I planned.
I broke a root that seemed important and nothing happened.
My notes didn't help us find the track again.
We were left without a solution.

1_3_4.text: The voices and the numbers diverged; there was no consensus.
I felt guilty for having messed things up.
The data became ambiguous with the humidity.
Nothing to report.

2_3_4.text: I was sure, but the trail didn't confirm.
I was guided to an empty spot.
The readings didn't match.
We came back defeated.

1_2_3_4.text: I tried to coordinate, but we didn't align.
I did something that erased clues.
The voices became confused.
No identified destination point.

1.text: I pushed the huge rock alone. It wasn't... a big deal. I mean, it was heavy, of course, but I managed it. Inside, there was a very narrow corridor, full of defensive markings. I preferred to turn back before entering. It didn't seem like a good place to face something alone.

2.text: I tried to move the rock, but... I couldn't move it alone. After analyzing it better, I saw it was a deliberately blocked entrance. I only entered slightly and noticed a narrow corridor, full of trap signs. I decided to retreat. I couldn't proceed alone without risking too much.

3.text: The rock was there, enormous, as if someone wanted to seal something. The voices said I shouldn't touch it. But I touched it anyway. It yielded a little... just a little. I entered enough to see a corridor funneling into old defenses. The voices became agitated. I preferred to return.

4.text: The rock blocking the entrance had impact marks. I calculated the force needed to displace it and only managed a minimal shift. I entered a few meters and observed a narrow corridor, clearly built for defense. With little room to maneuver, I decided to record an immediate retreat.

1_2.text: Lyra pushed the rock as if she were moving a barrel. I've never seen anything so... absurd.
I-it wasn't that big... it just... was poorly fitted, I think.
We only entered a bit and saw a narrow corridor full of defensive signs. I told her it was better to go back.
Yeah... it looked pretty dangerous. We retreated before something bad happened.

1_3.text: The rock... it simply moved out of the way when Lyra pushed. The voices fell silent. Even they were impressed.
I-I just pushed. Nothing major... please, don't tell anyone.
The corridor inside was too narrow... and had ancient defenses. The voices said not to follow.
I agreed. We returned before it became a problem.

1_4.text: Lyra's strength exceeds any standard estimate. The rock shifted almost half a meter with a single push.
P-please... pretend you didn't see that. I just wanted to clear the way.
The corridor was narrow and presented defensive structures. High risk of unfavorable combat.
Yes... we thought it best to return before going too far in.

2_3.text: We tried to move the rock together, but it only yielded a little. Enough to peek inside.
The voices were bothered by the corridor. They said it was a 'gorge for sacrifices'... I think.
There was no way to pass without high risk. The corridor was narrow and full of defenses.
We returned before any voice gained too much reason.

2_4.text: The rock was too heavy, but we managed to open a crack.
The corridor inside was narrow and designed for containment. High risk for two people.
I wasn't going to lie to myself: it seemed like a bad idea to continue.
We decided to return before the scenario became lethal.

3_4.text: The rock didn't move much... but enough to see inside. The voices became restless.
There was a narrow corridor, clearly defensive. No room for maneuvering.
The voices said something was waiting inside... something small, but wrong.
By probability, retreating was the best decision. We went back.

1_2_3.text: Lyra pushed the rock away alone. I've never seen anyone do that without help.
P-please, don't say that so loud... it was just technique.
The corridor seemed... alive. The voices murmured. It was narrow and full of defenses.
We returned before anything inside noticed us.

1_2_4.text: Lyra simply pushed the rock. It seemed impossible.
I... I just used force. It's no big deal...
The narrow corridor had clear defensive architecture. Advancement not recommended.
That's what I said: retreating was the right choice.

1_3_4.text: The rock moved as if it were light... thanks to Lyra.
I-it wasn't light. I just... pushed too hard, maybe.
The corridor had embedded defenses. Statistically risky to advance.
The voices grew tense. So we returned.

2_3_4.text: We tried together, but the rock barely moved.
Enough for me to hear the voices saying the narrow corridor was a trap.
Local geometry suggested extreme risk.
We returned before the worst happened.

1_2_3_4.text: Lyra pushed the rock alone... while I and the others just watched.
P-please... stop... it was just technique, seriously...
The narrow corridor seemed to breathe. The voices whispered about defense and ancient blood.
Very high risk. Immediate retreat decided by consensus.

1.text: I tried to move the rock, but it didn't budge. Not even a little. I stayed there pushing until my arms trembled. I couldn't even see the corridor inside. I returned before it got too dark.

2.text: I examined the rock, but couldn't move it. I couldn't even open a crack. Without that, I couldn't confirm if there was any corridor. I returned without progress.

3.text: The voices said not to touch the rock. I touched it anyway, but nothing happened. I couldn't move anything. I didn't see a corridor, I didn't see anything. I returned tired and somewhat frustrated.

4.text: The rock did not move even with the application of maximum adequate force. Without displacement, I couldn't analyze the interior. Report: total access failure.

1_2.text: Neither Lyra nor I could move the rock. I was surprised... and worried.
S-sorry... I tried, but it didn't move.
Without access to the interior, we had to go back.
Yeah... we didn't see any corridor.

1_3.text: The rock wouldn't move. The voices laughed... that didn't help.
I pushed, but it didn't even budge.
With no visible corridor, we returned.
Yes... it didn't work.

1_4.text: No application of force had any effect, not even Lyra's.
I tried. Honestly.
Without displacement, there was no way to see the interior.
So we went back.

2_3.text: We tried together, but the rock didn't even move.
The voices said it was 'sealed.' Whatever that means.
Without any crack, we didn't see any corridor.
We returned before it got dark.

2_4.text: The rock didn't move an inch.
Impossible to calculate the interior without a viewing angle.
We returned without progress.
Record closed.

3_4.text: The rock completely ignored us.
Insufficient force for minimal displacement.
No visible corridor.
Mandatory return.

1_2_3.text: Even with three people, the rock didn't yield.
I... I thought I could do it... but it didn't even move.
The voices only said 'locked'.
We returned without advances.

1_2_4.text: The rock didn't even tremble.
I'm sorry... I tried hard.
Without displacement, no analysis was possible.
We ended the mission without progress.

1_3_4.text: The rock stood still as if mocking us.
Even like this, I couldn't move it...
Corridor not observed. Total failure.
We returned frustrated.

2_3_4.text: Nothing made the rock move even a little.
The voices said 'not today'.
Without internal analysis, mission terminated.
We returned without seeing any corridor.

1_2_3_4.text: Four people... and nothing. The rock didn't even vibrate.
I... I don't know what happened. I was supposed to be able to...
The voices just laughed. I didn't like that.
Record: complete failure.
